so back them up and reinstall the system
you said all files, in a directory or the whole system?
ah, that's fixable
'sudo find /yourmount -type d -exec chmod 755 {} \;'
'sudo find /yourmount -type f -exec chmod 644 {} \;'
that will get the dirs and files readable, if you had executables, you'll have to chmod them 755 once you get that straight
any luck?
the top mount might not be 755
the commands I gave you assume the very top /yourmount is 755 already
just 'sudo chmod 755 /yourmount'  see if that fixes it
